item.title: Effects of local drug crisis evident in Kamsack, Sask.
item.description:
Effects of local drug crisis evident in Kamsack, Sask.

If the first step to recovery is admitting there's a problem, three First Nations around Kamsack, in east-central Saskatchewan, have reached that point. â€‹Leaders of the Federation of Saskatchewan Indian Nations and the Key, Cote and Keeseekoose First Nations sounded the alarm this week about a crisis in their communities.

item.title: Acid Drops by Andy Roberts
item.description:
Acid Drops by Andy Roberts

Acid Drops is a collection of essays, interviews, and creative pieces about psychedelic culture by renowned historian Andy Roberts.

item.title: How British 'cafe culture' drinks revolution ended in failure
item.description:
How British 'cafe culture' drinks revolution ended in failure

The extension of licensing hours in England and Wales has triggered a rise in binge drinking and an associated increase in mental and physical health problems, according to new research. A study conducted by economists at Lancaster University confirms that, while the relaxation of drinking hours has had little impact on the habits of normal drinkers, it has resulted in an increase in the number of people drinking heavily.

item.title: Rising opioid prescriptions following low-risk surgeries
item.description:
Rising opioid prescriptions following low-risk surgeries

Physicians are prescribing more opioid painkillers than ever before to patients undergoing common surgeries, according to new research. Opioid abuse and addiction is a growing concern in the U.S. Approximately 2.1 million Americans suffer from substance use disorders related to prescription opioid pain relievers and an estimated 467,000 Americans are addicted to heroin, with increasing recognition of the strong relationship between opioid use and heroin abuse.

item.title: Heroin antidote can help save lives
item.description:
Heroin antidote can help save lives

URBANA - Like a lot of longtime law enforcement officers, Sgt. Dan Coile has seen his share of heroin overdoses and, sometimes, the fatal consequences.The breathing of someone overdosing on heroin sounds like a loud snore, he said, with long pauses between breaths, "like they're trying to suck in air."

item.title: Ibogaine to Cure Addiction? A Hot Take on Mexico's Global Ibo Conference
item.description:
Ibogaine to Cure Addiction? A Hot Take on Mexico's Global Ibo Conference

I am sitting in the sun by the pool at my small hotel in Tepoztlan, Mexico, just after lunch, recovering from the Global Ibogaine Conference, which took place from March 14-16.

item.title: Drugs, Guns, Cash Seized in Drug Bust
item.description:
Drugs, Guns, Cash Seized in Drug Bust

KINGSTON - More than $50,000 worth of marijuana has landed five people behind bars in Luzerne County. Kingston officers seized 12 pounds of pot, five guns, and over $44,000 in cash in Thursday's bust. Police charged Matthew Klinges, 21, of Kingston; Matthew Mackiewicz, 18, of Forty Fort; and Jordan Stravolo, 22, of Kingston.

item.title: Supreme Court rejects challenge to Colorado marijuana law from other states
item.description:
Supreme Court rejects challenge to Colorado marijuana law from other states

The Supreme Court on Monday rejected a conservative challenge to the marijuana legalization laws adopted in Colorado and elsewhere that permit adults to buy, sell or use one ounce of the drug. By a 6-2 vote, the justices turned away a lawsuit brought by Nebraska and Oklahoma, whose state attorneys...

item.title: Heroin production explained
item.description:

item.title: 'Living in hell': mentally ill people in Indonesia chained and confined
item.description:
'Living in hell': mentally ill people in Indonesia chained and confined

Almost 40 years after Indonesia banned the practice of shackling people with mental health conditions, nearly 19,000 are still living in chains, or are locked up in institutions where they are vulnerable to abuse, according to a new report from Human Rights Watch (HRW).
